data.message: Core is changing too rapidly now for my taste, I would switch to Spring MVC and Java for the Back end Hibernate for your ORM, with AngularJS2 for the front end.
angularjs 1 is totally different from 2 it would be like revamping

Hello. This is the organizer of the AngularJS meetup in Sydney, ng-sydney

- Can I use Angular 2 in LTS projects?

Yes. Several people in my meetup have been reporting using it for work in the last 2 months at least, including enterprise apps.

- How about performance?

This is one of the main features in Angular 2!

- Is it stable?

Not 100%. There are still some changes happening with routing and forms. Not too crazy to be deal breakers though, except yes, expect a few.

Happy to take any further questions you may have.

I would personally not have trouble building Apps in Angular 2 and would have it in the list of acceptable technologies, in any case, it is a JS client side framework, so I would use it to build SPAs of limited/meduim size for my organization, something that could be built in 2-4 2 week sprints with 3 devs in a team. Otherwise, if you are talking about a large monolithic Application with lots of business functionality, I would go for an older UI framework that has stood the test of time as most of my business logic would be in the back end/ middleware.
